subsection.title: 1. Graph a linear equation by the intercept method

introduction.p: To graph a line by the intercept method, we find the x- and y-intercepts of the line and plot those points.

statement.p: Graph the equation 3x+2y=7 by the intercept method.

solution.p: A table with the two intercepts is shown below. We plot the intercepts and connect them with a straight line.

statement.p: Graph the line y=\dfrac{-4}{3}x+8 by the intercept method.
Graph the line \dfrac{x}{6}+\dfrac{y}{8}=-1 by the intercept method.

introduction.p: The values of the variables at the intercepts often tell us something important about a linear model

statement.p:
The temperature, T, in Nome was -12 \degree at noon and has been rising at a rate of 2 \degree per hour all day.
Write and graph an equaton for T in terms of h, the number of hours after noon.
Find the intercepts of the graph and interpret their meaning in the context of the problem situation.

sidebyside.p: An equation for T at time h is T=-12 +2h To find the T-intercept, we set h=0 and solve for T. T=-12+2(\alert{0})=-12

subsection.title: 3. Solve an equation for one of the variables

introduction.p: It is usually easier to study a model and draw its graph if it is in the form y = \text{starting value} + \text{rate} \times x To put an equation into this form, we want to "isolate" the output variable on one side of the equation.
